newsitem.title: UK: Corrupt British MPs face jail under new law.
newsitem.headline: Corrupt British MPs face jail under new law.

text.p: Corrupt British members of parliament will face up to seven years in jail under tough new proposals to be announced on Monday, officials said.
Home Secretary (interior minister) Jack Straw will detail plans for a bill intended to root out parliamentary corruption, or sleaze, from British public life.
The issue came to a head in the election which the Labour Party won by a landslide on May 1.

Former BBC war correspondent Martin Bell, standing as an independent "anti-sleaze" candidate, defeated sitting Conservative MP Neil Hamilton, who denies accepting cash in return for asking questions in parliament.
The Home Office said the new Labour government wanted to legislate as soon as possible but faced a packed parliamentary programme.
Anti-corruption legislation was therefore unlikely to find its way on to the statute books before late next year.
MPs are not at present covered by laws on bribery in public bodies and must be disciplined by the House of Commons rather than the courts.
Although the last years of the defeated Conservative government were overshadowed by allegations of sleaze, Labour has run into the problem since coming to power.
Labour's Mohammed Sarwar, Britain's first Moslem MP, is under investigation followng allegations he broke election law by lending 5,000 pounds ($8,000) to a rival candidate.
